children.caption: A galu is a variety of livestock that is the offspring of a bull and a dzo cow.
children.title: Galu

children.caption: A black foal is a young horse (around one year old) with black coloring.
children.title: Black Foal

children.caption: A horse that is completely black.
children.title: Black Horse

children.caption: A black kyangkyang is a red horse with a small amount of black mixed in its coat.
children.title: Black Kyangkyang

children.caption: A black ngongo is a horse whose coloring mixes gray and black.
children.title: Black Ngongo

children.caption: A gyogyo is a horse whose body is white but with orange undertones.
children.title: Gyogyo

children.caption: A gülma is a horse with an especially skillful gait.
children.title: Gülma

children.caption: A khakham is a horse with dark brown hair.
children.title: Khamkham

children.caption: A kyangkyang is a red-colored horse. Many people consider these horses to be the pinnacle of all horse breeds.
children.title: Kyangkyang

children.caption: This refers to a mare who leads a calf.
children.title: Mare with Calf

children.caption: A moksé is a white horse whose face, feet, and chest are red.
children.title: Moksé

children.caption: A mottled gyogyo is a white horse with many pale yellow spots on its body.
children.title: Mottled Gyogyo

children.caption: A multicolored horse with black body but white feet, tail, back, and face.
children.title: Multicolor Horse

children.caption: A multicolor kyangkyang is a horse whose body is red, but with white markings under and on the lower portions of its limbs.
children.title: Multicolor Kyangkyang

children.caption: Ngongo is a variety of horse whose coloring is a mix of black and white.
children.title: Ngongo

children.caption: A racehorse is a horse which competes in demonstrations of skill.
children.title: Racehorse

children.caption: A rara is a white horse, called gyara and gyagya in the nomadic dialect of Kham.
children.title: Rara

children.caption: A rato is a white horse whose tail and feet are a light red color.
children.title: Rato

children.caption: A red gyogyo is a white horse with reddish markings on its body.
children.title: Red Gyogyo

children.caption: A show horse is a horse that participates in demonstrations of running prowess.
children.title: Show Horse

children.caption: A spotted black horse is a black horse with white spots on its forehead.
children.title: Spotted Black Horse

children.caption: A spotted gyogyo is a black and white horse with spots of one color or the other on its head.
children.title: Spotted Gyogyo

children.caption: A spotted ngongo is a ngongo with white spots on its head.
children.title: Spotted Ngongo

children.caption: A yellow foal is a young horse with cream coloring.
children.title: Yellow Foal

children.caption: A black gya is a white sheep with black markings around its eyes and on its limbs.
children.title: Black Gya

children.caption: This refers to a mother sheep who leads her lamb.
children.title: Ewe with Lamb

children.caption: A four-horned ram is a ram with four horns; these are commonly released as part of animal liberation rites.
children.title: Four-Horned Ram

children.caption: A gyasé is a white sheep with yellow undertones in its coat.
children.title: Gyasé

children.caption: A gyato lamb is a small puffy-faced lamb with dark red markings around its eyes and on its snout and feet.
children.title: Gyato Lamb

children.caption: A gyazak is a completely white sheep with yellow undertones throughout its entire coat.
children.title: Gyazak

children.caption: A khamzhé lamb is a lamb whose body is covered with a mix of yellow, white, and black spots.
children.title: Khamzhé Lamb

children.caption: A many-horned ewe is considered extremely auspicious.
children.title: Lucky Many-Horned Ewe

children.caption: A meat sheep refers to a ram that is slaughtered and eaten.
children.title: Meat Sheep

children.caption: A mottled blue sheep is primarily blue-colored, but with many white spots.
children.title: Mottled Blue Sheep

children.caption: A mottled red lamb is a small lamb whose coloring is a mix of red, mottled black, and mottled white.
children.title: Mottled Red Lamb

children.caption: A multicolor ewe is white with yellow markings on half of its face, stomach, and feet.
children.title: Multicolor Ewe

children.caption: A multicolor ram is a ram whose mostly white coat also contains some black and yellow coloring.
children.title: Multicolor Ram

children.caption: A puffy face lamb is a lamb with a puffy neck and face, and dark red markings on its chest and four limbs.
children.title: Puffy Face Lamb

children.caption: This refers to a sheep with a puffy neck and face, and dark red markings on its chest and limbs.
children.title: Puffy Face Sheep

children.caption: A red gya is a variety of sheep with a white body and a small amount of red coloring on its face and limbs.
children.title: Red Gya

children.caption: A tata is a sheep whose white coat contains strong yellow undertones.
children.title: Tata

children.caption: A tsermo is a three-year-old female sheep that has reached sexual maturity.
children.title: Tsermo

children.caption: A tolé is a variety of livestock that is the offspring of a bull and a female yak.
children.title: Tolé

children.caption: This refers to a blue-colored yak.
children.title: Blue Yak

children.caption: A dredré is a yak whose body is black, but whose snout is either grey or yellow.
children.title: Dredré

children.caption: A dunglé is a yak whose body is entirely black but whose head is white.
children.title: Dunglé

children.caption: A protected dri is a female yak that has been released as part of an animal liberation rite.
children.title: Protected Dri

children.caption: A sumyarma is a three-year old female yak calf.
children.title: Sumyarma

children.caption: A trima is a one-year old female yak calf.
children.title: Trima

children.caption: A yarma is a two-year old female yak calf.
children.title: Yarma

children.caption: A gyagya is a black-bodied yak with yellow coloring.
children.title: Gyagya

children.caption: A hornless yak whose lower body is black with a small amount of orange mixed in.
children.title: Gyarima

children.caption: A yak whose hair is black, but whose…
children.title: Gyasema

children.caption: A hornless yak is a yak lacking horns.
children.title: Hornless Yak

children.caption: A sesé is a yak whose body is primarily black, but whose shoulders, hips, and tail have a mix of black and white.
children.title: Hrehré

children.caption: A khamka is a yak with a dark red body and a white face.
children.title: Khamka

children.caption: A khampa is a yak whose coloring is a mix of yellow and black.
children.title: Khampa

children.caption: A breeding yak is an uncastrated yak.
children.title: Breeding Yak

children.caption: A mottled blue yak is a variety of yak whose coloring is blue with either many white or black spots.
children.title: Mottled Blue Yak

children.caption: A multicolor yak is a yak whose coat is a mix of black and white.
children.title: Multicolor Yak

children.caption: A mumu is a yak whose body is completely black and whose face has a rectangular white spot on it.
children.title: Mumu

children.caption: A rakrak is a yak whose coat is a mix of white and red.
children.title: Rakrak

children.caption: A rokrok is a variety of purely black yak commonly used in yak races.
children.title: Rokrok

children.caption: A sesé is a greyish colored yak.
children.title: Sesé

children.caption: A spotted yak is a variety of pure black yak with white spots on its forehead.
children.title: Spotted Yak

children.caption: A sumyar is a three-year old yak calf which still drinks its mother’s milk.
children.title: Sumyar

children.caption: A three-horned yak is an extremely rare variety of yak possessing three horns.
children.title: Three-Horned Yak

children.caption: A twin pair of two-year-old yak calves.
children.title: Twin Yaru

children.caption: This refers to variety of white-bodied yaks that are found in abundance in the Huaré region of Gansu.
children.title: White Yak

children.caption: A white yaru is a two-year-old white yak calf.
children.title: White Yaru

children.caption: A white-shouldered yak is a variety of yak whose body is white from the shoulder to the upper chest.
children.title: White-Shouldered Yak

children.caption: A yellow rokrok is a yak whose black coat is tinged with a slight amount of yellow.
children.title: Yellow Rokrok

children.caption: A yellow yak is a variety of yellow-colored yak.
children.title: Yellow Yak

children.caption: A multicolor mumu is a variety of yak whose body is completely white, except for its shoulders and rump, which are black

children.title: Kagyü

children.caption: Activity rituals are rituals whose chief goal is to incite a deity to accomplish one or more of the "four types of activities" (las bzhi).
children.title: Activity ritual

children.caption: An agricultural ritual is enacted to ensure a good harvest, to protect a harvest, or else as thanksgiving for a good harvest.
A prayer for a good harvest aims to ensure a good harvest, or increase the yield of a harvest.
children.title: Prayer for a good harvest

children.caption: Procession of scriptures in the fields is a ritual at the center of which is the circumambulation of the canon around the fields.
children.title: Procession of scriptures in the fields
Ritual directed at the gods of the fields (often Brahma)

children.caption: This is a type of ritual to ensure good harvests, or to protect harvests from natural or supernatural threats.
A ritual to ransom the harvest is a harvest ritual that uses an effigy or other substitute for the crops or farmer to protect the harvest.
children.title: Ritual to ransom the harvest
Ritual for a good harvest
Agricultural ritual

children.caption: An alchemical ritual has as its goal the extraction of the potency or "essence" (bcud) from substances.

children.title: Five meats and five nectars (alchemical ritual)
Alchemical ritual by substance being transformed
Alchemical ritual to counter old age
Alchemical ritual

children.caption: An animal-related ritual is designed to protect or benefit animals, domesticated or wild.

children.title: Protection of beings who live inside and outside the body
Animal-related ritual

children.caption: A bodhicitta-generation ritual serves to generate bodhicitta - "the mind of enlightenment" - in front of a master or a visualized deity.
children.title: Bodhicitta-generation ritual

children.caption: A clay-tablet ritual is one accompanying the making of small stūpa-shaped images known as tsha tsha.
children.title: Clay-tablet ritual

children.caption: A commitment fulfillment ritual is performed to fulfill the religious commitments or vows taken as part of a tantric initiation.
This refers to the daily rites performed to fulfill commitments acquired via one's taking of the bodhisattva vows.
children.title: Bodhisattva vow daily ritual

children.caption: This is a ritual recited six times a day to fulfill commitments of bodhisattva or tantric vows and anuttarayoga tantric empowerments.
children.title: Six session (ritual)
Commitment fulfillment ritual

children.caption: This is a ritual involving the confession, and thereby the expiation, of negative deeds.

children.title: Confession of transgressions of tantric vows/commitments

children.caption: These are rituals for confessing, atoning for, making amends for, and repairing one's relationship to (chiefly) protector deities.
children.title: Ritual for making amends
General confession of breaking the three vows
Confession of eating meat on the same day it was butchered
Confession ritual

children.caption: These are rituals for consecrating physical objects such as images, stūpas, ritual implements, places, and so forth.

children.title: Consecration of (amulets that bring) liberation through wearing
Rituals for filling statues with printed dhāraṇīs
Consecration
Rituals for guiding/helping the dead [e.g., into a pure land]
Rituals to prevent the deceased from returning as a ghost
Transference of consciousness [of a dying or deceased person]

Rituals for determining the death hour

For person who has died in old age
Bon subjugation [of negative forces that disturb the dead]
Weekly ritual until day the 49th day

For the success of one’s work

To stop the pain of a burn

Using the first word heard when one comes out of a house
